author: bridge-bot
content: <vdWijden> We're even disconnecting geth nodes... so probably a geth issue here^^

author: bridge-bot
content:
<vdWijden> > Client implementations should enforce limits on protocol message sizes. The underlying RLPx transport limits the size of a single message to 16.7 MiB. The practical limits for the eth protocol are lower, typically 10 MiB. If a received message is larger than the limit, the peer should be disconnected.

Looks like we need an update here: https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/eth.md

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Should we go lower on max block size?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Should we go lower on max block size EIP than 10MB?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> And looks like EL has implicit block limit also of 10MB or will be disconnected from p2p?

author: bridge-bot
content: <vdWijden> Yep, removing the limit on my side made it possible to sync, almost at head already

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> We (or others) might have built some blocks too big at one point?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> As there is no limit on blocksize for a valid block

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Taps EIP https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9658

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams>

author: bridge-bot
content: <gakonst> What's the origin of the block size limit 10mb? Why cant we crack it up? I've heard that Go's json pkg is garbage on Engine Api, is that the issue?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@gakonst**
> What's the origin of the block size limit 10mb? Why cant we crack it up? I've heard that Go's json pkg is garbage on Engine Api, is that the issue?
Issue is there isn't a block size limit; but there is a p2p message limit both in CL gossip and EL devp2p of 10MiB

Raw udp also isn't a great protocol for huge contiguous blocks of data

author: bridge-bot
content:
<gakonst> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Issue is there isn't a block size limit; but there is a p2p message limit both in CL gossip and EL devp2p of 10MiB

Raw udp also isn't a great protocol for huge contiguous blocks of data
Where is that limit coming from?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> devp2p https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/eth.md#ethereum-wire-protocol-eth

author: bridge-bot
content:
<gakonst> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> devp2p https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/blob/master/caps/eth.md#ethereum-wire-protocol-eth
Is this fundamental? Should we just fix it?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> CL gossip https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/bellatrix/p2p-interface.md#gossipsub

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@gakonst**
> Is this fundamental? Should we just fix it?
Then you have other DoS attacks to start working around like slow loris etc.

To hit it your block needs to almost completely full of zeros; is that a type of block we want to work hard to enable? Is there any value in such blocks?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Non-zero blocks (without execution) hit the limit at 400MGas

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> zero blocks (without execution) hit the limit at 100MGas

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> I suggest there is no value in enabling larger zero blocks; because if there was value, they wouldn't be entirely zeros; but have some content or other execution

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Doesn't seem worth spending time on, so just cap at the current network limits? (or lower as now that cap allows us to directly control max validator bandwidth)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Doesn't seem worth spending time on, so just cap at the current network limits? (or lower as now that cap allows us to directly control max validator bandwidth)
instead introducing a hard cap  on the RLP size that impacts the pricing mechanism, solving the problem by something like doubling the costs for zero bytes is cleaner.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> instead introducing a hard cap  on the RLP size that impacts the pricing mechanism, solving the problem by something like doubling the costs for zero bytes is cleaner.
you already have a limit tho - you would just make that limit safer

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> instead introducing a hard cap  on the RLP size that impacts the pricing mechanism, solving the problem by something like doubling the costs for zero bytes is cleaner.
higher will absolutely fail; there is in reality a hard cap, changing pricing mechanisms will not change that there is a hard cap; so put the hard cap in on blocksize why pretend its not there?

If in addition; want a more elegant pricing solution so the hard cap is never hit, sure. But don't need to rush something maybe not fully thought out in, and how does the pricing adjust to an increasing gaslimit?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Do zero bytes become more expensive as the gaslimit increases? (which seems a bit odd)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> instead introducing a hard cap  on the RLP size that impacts the pricing mechanism, solving the problem by something like doubling the costs for zero bytes is cleaner.
bumping calldata price is not clean. You are not solving the core issue, this is a band-aid on the hard cap

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> The solution to inconsistencies is to fix the inconsistency through making caps and limits "consistent" (in this case)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> Is this hardcap on the engine api something that cannot change?
After the 10 MiB, what's the next limit we will run into, do we have an overview here?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> Is this hardcap on the engine api something that cannot change?
After the 10 MiB, what's the next limit we will run into, do we have an overview here?
Is CL p2p gossip limit, EL devp2p limit, not engine api

author: bridge-bot
content: <nero_eth> Right, but can it be raised?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> Right, but can it be raised?
Theorically yes but last time the CL devs were not inclined to

author: bridge-bot
content:
<parithoshj> re: **@nero_eth**
> Is this hardcap on the engine api something that cannot change?
After the 10 MiB, what's the next limit we will run into, do we have an overview here?
likely if we're shoving so much data around, json deserializing becomes a bottleneck (unsubstantiated opinion)

author: bridge-bot
content: <lrozmej> 10+mb blocks will cause lot of latency issues

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> Anyway - just generally the extra cap is needed because it is a bug to have inconsistents caps regardless of fee markets. First and foremost, this is a security issue and you will have an hard cap regardless in some shape or form

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Also is 80Mb (8x10MiB); so would take 1.6secs to transfer to single peer at recommended upload for the new hardware specs of a producer

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> What does raising it help?

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> It only enables degenerate blocks; not useful work blocks, so why do it?

author: bridge-bot
content: <KamilChNethermind> Should we increase that on perfnet and try cooking blocks higher than that and see the implications? Guessing vs actually seeing what it will cause?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> What does raising it help?
not saying we should raise. Just trying to understand what limit we are facing here, why it's in place, but makes sense.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> not saying we should raise. Just trying to understand what limit we are facing here, why it's in place, but makes sense.
It is also over raw Udp which is a terrible protocol for larger data transfers; isn't what it was designed for

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> I would not worry about fee markets too much because the cap is there already. Just in another form. It does have the nice property to introduce a form of "shitty" dim calldata but it is an after effect and it is probably a directional improvement rather than an hindrance

author: bridge-bot
content: <nero_eth> I'm all for having txpool limits, but for consensus rules, I'd prefer relying on appropriate pricing than a reachable hard cap size. We can have a hard cap in addition, but it would need to adapt with the gas limit and sould initially be set such that it won't be hit.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> I'm all for having txpool limits, but for consensus rules, I'd prefer relying on appropriate pricing than a reachable hard cap size. We can have a hard cap in addition, but it would need to adapt with the gas limit and sould initially be set such that it won't be hit.
but you already have it - it is  a bug not having it as a rule

author: bridge-bot
content: <nero_eth> but today you cannot reach the 10 MiB?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> I'm all for having txpool limits, but for consensus rules, I'd prefer relying on appropriate pricing than a reachable hard cap size. We can have a hard cap in addition, but it would need to adapt with the gas limit and sould initially be set such that it won't be hit.
Sure; not against that. But there is a limit, its just not recognised in block building/validation

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> but today you cannot reach the 10 MiB?
But we will with 150M. It is a protocol bug not to have constistency across the board

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> but today you cannot reach the 10 MiB?
Can at 42MGas pre-Pectra and 102MGas post-Pectra with single tx filling block that is all zeros

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Can at 42MGas pre-Pectra and 102MGas post-Pectra with single tx filling block that is all zeros
Can a tx that is an entire block of all zeros serve a useful purpose?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@FunnyGiulio**
> But we will with 150M. It is a protocol bug not to have constistency across the board
Right, so it's not a bug or a limit today. It's just one of many unreachable limits. If we want to prepare for higher gas limits, we can increase the limits (such that the worst-case block can't hit them) or price things differently.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Can a tx that is an entire block of all zeros serve a useful purpose?
I agree, this is an attack but having size limit is just not the cleanest solution to this.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> Right, so it's not a bug or a limit today. It's just one of many unreachable limits. If we want to prepare for higher gas limits, we can increase the limits (such that the worst-case block can't hit them) or price things differently.
Is the reason why the gaslimit increase on mainnet was stopped at 36M

Gaslimit increases are coupled to this worse case; so we should remove this unnecessary coupling on the gaslimit

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> Right, so it's not a bug or a limit today. It's just one of many unreachable limits. If we want to prepare for higher gas limits, we can increase the limits (such that the worst-case block can't hit them) or price things differently.
This is not the correct solution. You have issues with inconsistent caps so you make them consistent. At least this is how I see it

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> Right, so it's not a bug or a limit today. It's just one of many unreachable limits. If we want to prepare for higher gas limits, we can increase the limits (such that the worst-case block can't hit them) or price things differently.
I am saying this is a conceptual bug. The clean solution is to fix what conceptually does not work (at least this is how I see it)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@FunnyGiulio**
> I am saying this is a conceptual bug. The clean solution is to fix what conceptually does not work (at least this is how I see it)
Would still want the limit applied for safety regardless of whatever pricing solution was devised to ensure it was never hit

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> ðŸ˜‰

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> I am mostly just speaking about "proper" solution here. Raising gas prices gives the removal of such bottleneck as a second order consequence. I think a proper solution is fix what is closer to the first-order cause

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Would still want the limit applied for safety regardless of whatever pricing solution was devised to ensure it was never hit
I am mostly just speaking about "proper" solution here. Raising gas prices gives the removal of such bottleneck as a second order consequence. I think a proper solution is fix what is closer to the first-order cause

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@FunnyGiulio**
> I am saying this is a conceptual bug. The clean solution is to fix what conceptually does not work (at least this is how I see it)
If we can come up with a pricing model that means it is not hit; that doesn't mean we shouldn't also add the hard cap.

No mater the situation, we should add the hardcap, so we should add the hardcap :)

author: bridge-bot
content:

We can have some buffer to never even get close to the 10 MiB.

content:

> What if we instead just limit the amout of calldata bytes that can be used per block, not touching the RPC? This would not affect attestations, EL requests, withdrawals, etc.

author: bridge-bot
content:

with a size on RLP, I could throw out attestations to get a big, well-paying transaction on-chain. With applying the limit you want on calldata, you'd contain it's impact.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Is kinda what it is? everything else is a given
given; it that it has to be taken into account

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> The block cap is empirical. It is based on empirical limits. Tx-level cap is not obvious

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> with a size on RLP, I could throw out attestations to get a big, well-paying transaction on-chain. With applying the limit you want on calldata, you'd contain it's impact.
attestations are in the CL wrapper, so can't be thrown out by the EL block limit

author: bridge-bot
content: <nero_eth> not tx-level caps, still only block level caps. But you could also have a tx-limit cap and some "additional space" claimable by all transactions in the block.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<FunnyGiulio> re: **@nero_eth**
> not tx-level caps, still only block level caps. But you could also have a tx-limit cap and some "additional space" claimable by all transactions in the block.
But why not a block level cap? This is essentially it

content:

no, is the EL payload size

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> CL worst case is 128kb - this is why my EIP has a margin of 512Kb to account for headers and beacon blcok

author: bridge-bot
content:

> no, is the EL payload size
Proposal is EL block cannot be > (10MiB - 512KiB)

content: <ben_a_adams> So have 512KiB for whatever the CL wants to add

> I do see why the size cap is a pragmatic short term fix. It's easier than some repricing but not the most appropriate way to solve it.
Can you elaborate why?

author: bridge-bot

author: bridge-bot
content:

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@FunnyGiulio**
> Can you elaborate why?
it's easy from implementation and reasoning standpoint. In the end we should price resources properly.

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Also means if someone sends you a > 10MiB block you can immediately drop rather than having to fully download, parse, workout how each transactions uses gas and how is that priced before dropping as over gaslimit

author: bridge-bot
content: <nero_eth> fair point yeah. And maybe the market will be less affected as we might think, if we don't go insanely high with the gas limit.

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> See it as a fast rejection mechanism :)

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Doesn't mean we shouldn't also do better pricing; but gives time to research that while increasing gaslimit, rather than having to wait for everyone to come to consensus on the right pricing approach before increasing gaslimit

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> Or is a bug preventing gaslimit increases; fix the bug.

Is a mispricing in markets, fix the pricing

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Slightly independent (also slightly related); first we'd need to do regardless as is security hole

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Secondary, maybe even lower limits as that size block goes beyond recommended bandwidth with slot time allocations

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> So if you make a block that big, attach 9 blobs and have the recommend upload -> recommend download you will get reorged

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> But might not be a problem as likely won't have the txs to create it unless you are one of the top 2 builders (and have the private orderflow)

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Which is a different issue ðŸ˜‰

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@adietrichs**
> also - can someone explain again why this size limit is so hard to remove from clients? like, why is it hard to set it to e.g. 100MB?

author: bridge-bot
content: <FunnyGiulio> randomly exposing attack vectors to the public on this blessed day

author: bridge-bot
content:
<notnotstorm_p> re: **@nero_eth**
> fair point yeah. And maybe the market will be less affected as we might think, if we don't go insanely high with the gas limit.
whether or not the fee markets get screwed up by a block cap depends on the frequency of blocks bumping up against the cap

if it happens maybe <1% or <0.1% or 0% of the time it doesn't really matter

need a model that predicts this frequency as a function of gas_limit and cap_size. and that frequency reveals whether UX will be harmed, which is the ultimate thing we're trying to avoid

author: bridge-bot
content:
<notnotstorm_p> but overall agree with the idea that the cap is already there, it's just implicit for a variety of reasons. good to make it explicit which will avoid some bad edge cases

can also add a fee market later on, but I see this as only necessary if bandwidth becomes the major bottleneck and the gas limit reaches a level where block sizes regularly bump against the max size

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> 100MiB blocks will take 16secs for an attester to download with the recommended bandwidth; which is longer than a 12sec slot
I thought the concern this cap is trying to address is not propagation time, but EL <> CL communication?

author: bridge-bot
content:
<adietrichs> Ofc propagation time is a bottleneck at some point, but so is compute, so is state reads, so is state writes, so is state growth, etc.

Is propagation time the one where we are the closest to hitting the limit? Otherwise that is irrelevant

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> Would be really good if we could start to have a systematic overview of all of this: all the different potential bottlenecks and the average / p95 / worst case current load for them. So we could track how close to the limit we are for each of them

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@adietrichs**
> Ofc propagation time is a bottleneck at some point, but so is compute, so is state reads, so is state writes, so is state growth, etc.

Is propagation time the one where we are the closest to hitting the limit? Otherwise that is irrelevant
We hit the limit in the CL gossip p2p spec and EL devp2p spec at 10MiB; where the rules say disconnect the peers

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> Ah, so that is not EL<>CL uncompressed communication, but network communication of compressed payloads? Sorry about my terrible terminology

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> So the >10MB block cannot be propagated (CL) nor synced (EL) by the network protocol specs

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> And it is hard to remove that constant? I understand that that doesnâ€™t magically make bandwidth more plentiful, but my point is that other resources also run into limits, first point is just to remove these "cliffs"

content: <nero_eth> yeah snappy is inefficient here. With 36m, we get to 3.43 Mib. 3x gives us the 100m gas..

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams>

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Recommendation, limit amount that can be decompressed

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Looks like snappy is x21 for 0 bytes

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> 
yeah, we knew about this big gap between compressed and uncompressed sizes for zeros for over a year. The problem is see with big objects is bandwidth - but this then only applies to compressed sizes. You cannot do zip bombs with also consuming computation because the pricing for non-zeros is significantly higher.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> yeah, we knew about this big gap between compressed and uncompressed sizes for zeros for over a year. The problem is see with big objects is bandwidth - but this then only applies to compressed sizes. You cannot do zip bombs with also consuming computation because the pricing for non-zeros is significantly higher.
So if was 10MiB for compressed, that would be 210MiB uncompressed

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> yeah, we knew about this big gap between compressed and uncompressed sizes for zeros for over a year. The problem is see with big objects is bandwidth - but this then only applies to compressed sizes. You cannot do zip bombs with also consuming computation because the pricing for non-zeros is significantly higher.
Doesn't matter; decompression is before running it

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> You don't need to pay anything

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Isn't about good actors properly paying for tx; is fast reject for badactors

author: bridge-bot
content:
<nero_eth> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> So if was 10MiB for compressed, that would be 210MiB uncompressed
With 36m, the max compressed is ~1.3 MiB. 
Downloading and unpacking 0.5 MiB object and get a 10 MiB object isn't a problem since you do it locally. Those 10mib would come with no execution.
Not saying we shouldn't fix the limit but saying "10 MiB compressed" is far from realistic.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@nero_eth**
> With 36m, the max compressed is ~1.3 MiB. 
Downloading and unpacking 0.5 MiB object and get a 10 MiB object isn't a problem since you do it locally. Those 10mib would come with no execution.
Not saying we shouldn't fix the limit but saying "10 MiB compressed" is far from realistic.
Ignore gas limit; thats only applied on executing block, you have to decompress it before the gaslimit is applied and block may be intentionally invalid

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@ben_a_adams**
> Ignore gas limit; thats only applied on executing block, you have to decompress it before the gaslimit is applied and block may be intentionally invalid
If you want to troll the network and pay Eth for it that's one thing; but you shouldn't be able to do it for free ðŸ˜‰

author: sky.cactus
content: Why does being public cause you to be unable to discuss freely?

author: glasscipher
content: I believe the issue is that discussing certain bugs in public might motivate malicious actors

author: sky.cactus
content: I can't imagine anything other than critical security vulnerabilities in clients that affect mainnet being worthy of keeping private, and it is incredibly worrying to me that people are even considering, much less lobbying for, more private communication.  It feels like that goes strongly against the ethos of Ethereum Core Development.  cc <@552133098075193354>

author: sky.cactus
content: Are we talking about bugs that are live on mainnet, exploitable today, and not already disclosed or well known?

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., 0-days

author: bridge-bot
content:
<ben_a_adams> re: **@gas_limit_testing_bot**
> <sky.cactus> [reply]: Why does being public cause you to be unable to discuss freely?
Discovered vulnerabilities and we can't be rude to each other and say their clients are weaksauce ðŸ˜‰

author: glasscipher
content: Even if we aren't talking about known zero-days, discussions might uncover them.

author: sky.cactus
content: In the case of the former, I feel like that should be discussed in a security war room with maybe 5 people, not in a channel discussing gas limit testing with many people.  In the case of the latter, I see no reason why you can't call out clients as weak sauce in public.  ðŸ˜„

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Other Ethereum clients

author: sky.cactus
content: I see no problem with calling out any client as weak sauce in public.  ðŸ˜„

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> hmm doesn't delete messages; this bridge bot is weaksauce

author: glasscipher
content: Neither do I, but that wasn't my point

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe this simplifies to the argument that nothing should be open source because people may find and exploit bugs.

author: sky.cactus
content: Any discussion about any code or protocol or testing may reveal bugs that are exploitable by people.  I don't think this being a possibility means that we should start engaging in closed source development practices.

author: ben_a_adams
content: Basically we are trying to attack and find where and how every EL breaks; to then fix it. Is more likely that it will uncover 0-days than other conversations (or people reading it think of how to extend the issues into a 0-day, that we might not have noticed)

author: glasscipher
content: No, having a private discussion doesn't mean closing source.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is a closed source development practice, even if you open source the code in the end, the process is happening behind closed doors (contrary to the open source ethos).

author: ben_a_adams
content: but is also valuable discussions on consequences and how to resolve by EIPs (if needed) that should probably be public so is a balance

author: glasscipher
content: "closed source development practice" -- don't know who writes the rules on that. is private disclosure of 0-days a closed source dev practice?

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree that there are risks to open source development.  Obfuscation and closed door practices provide a small amount of protection.  However, the general claim is that the benefits of open development practices and source outweigh the risks save for discussion about found 0-days.

author: glasscipher
content: we are kind of veering off topic. maybe this discussion should be had in a different channel

author: ben_a_adams
content: Vulnerability testing is normally private even in open source

author: ben_a_adams
content: I think that's the main contention

author: ben_a_adams
content: Hopefully all the issues are above the current gaslimit though ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Happy to move it to a different channel.  I do think it is an important conversation to have.  I feel Ethereum has been drifting away from its historic "radically open" ethos lately with all of the secret Telegram Channels and such so I would like to continue this discussion *somewhere*.  This isn't the first channel that has been revealed to be a secret channel that a privileged group has access to and the public doesn't.

author: ben_a_adams
content: Isn't a very old channel ðŸ˜…  And isn't really secret alpha other than where issues are; I imagine it was opened when their started to be more discussion of how to fix things that had protocol implications rather than just bug fixes to be done

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Might set up UI on perfnet; see how unhappy it is

author: bridge-bot
content: <ben_a_adams> Spicy

author: bridge-bot
content:
<notnotstorm_p> > it is incredibly worrying to me that people are even considering, much less lobbying for, more private communication

> engaging in closed source development practices

> I feel Ethereum has been drifting away from its historic "radically open" ethos lately

this is tbh a ridiculous+impractical attitude. you can argue the utility of having this specific channel be open or closed but lets stop with the hyperbolic appeals to idealism without any consideration of specifics. this is cia sabotage field manual style BS that has been harming ethereum core dev processes for years

there are many cases where it is good for communication to be open. there are many cases where it is good for it to be closed

I lean toward closed on this particular channel because it is somewhat security related and also there are other lines of communication that have been recently been growing for diseminating information about ethereum's gas limit
